text: I don't know about your mom, but my mom doesn't write code and almost all my friends throughout my life reached out for help. Like, 'Anton, I need to build something. How do I find a great software engineer?' And we are building for this 99% of the population who don't write code.
speaker: Anton Osika
context: Lenny asks Anton to explain what Lovable is and why they're building it. Anton describes Lovable as a personal AI software engineer where you describe an idea and get a fully working product. He explains their motivation for creating this tool - to serve the vast majority of people who have ideas but can't code and struggle to find good software engineers to build their products.
text_ko: 네 엄마는 어떨지 모르겠지만, 제 엄마는 코딩(coding)을 안 하시고, 지금까지 만난 거의 모든 친구들이 도움을 청하러 연락했어요. 친구들이 "안톤, 뭔가 만들고 싶은데, 훌륭한 소프트웨어 엔지니어(software engineer)는 어떻게 찾지?"라고 물어보곤 했어요. 우리는 코딩을 하지 않는 사람들 전체의 99%를 위해 이걸 만들고 있어요.
text_zh: 我不知道你妈妈怎么样，但我妈肯定不会写代码，我身边的朋友基本上都来找过我帮忙。就是那种"安东，我想做个什么东西，上哪儿找靠谱的程序员啊？"我们做的产品就是为了这99%不会写代码的普通人。
text_es: No sé tu mamá, pero la mía no programa y casi todos mis amigos a lo largo de mi vida me han pedido ayuda. Como que "Antón, necesito crear algo. ¿Cómo encuentro un buen desarrollador de software?" Y estamos construyendo para ese 99% de la población que no programa.

text: The best word for a great product is that it's lovable. A lot of jargon that I like to use to emphasize what we should be striving for is building a minimum lovable product and then building a lovable product and then building an absolutely lovable product. So I took that jargon with me in the company name.
speaker: Anton Osika
context: Lenny asks Anton how he decided on the name 'Lovable' for his company, commenting that it's so sweet. Anton explains his philosophy around product development, describing his belief that the best descriptor for a great product is that it's 'lovable.' He shares his framework of progressing from minimum lovable product to absolutely lovable product, which influenced his choice of company name.
text_ko: 훌륭한 제품을 한마디로 표현할 때 가장 좋은 단어는 '사랑받는(lovable)'이에요. 제가 우리가 지향해야 할 걸 강조하려고 자주 쓰는 전문 용어가 있는데, '최소로 사랑받을 수 있는 제품(minimum lovable product)'을 만들고, 그다음엔 '사랑받는 제품(lovable product)'을 만들고, 결국엔 '완전히 사랑받는 제품(absolutely lovable product)'을 만드는 거예요. 그래서 그 표현을 회사 이름에도 담았어요.
text_zh: 要形容一个出色的产品，我觉得最好的词就是"让人爱不释手"。我特别喜欢用一个说法来强调我们应该追求的目标，就是先做出一个最小可爱产品(minimum lovable product)，然后做成可爱产品(lovable product)，最后做成绝对可爱产品(absolutely lovable product)。所以我把这个理念带到了公司名字里。
text_es: La mejor palabra para describir un gran producto es que sea adorable. Hay mucha jerga que me gusta usar para enfatizar hacia qué deberíamos apuntar: crear un producto mínimo adorable (minimum lovable product), luego un producto adorable (lovable product) y después un producto absolutamente adorable (absolutely lovable product). Así que me llevé esa jerga conmigo al nombre de la empresa.

text: Doing a bit of everything. Being a generalist, I think much more important than it used to be. If I'm putting together a product team today, I would really obsess about getting as many skill sets as possible for each person I hire.
speaker: Anton Osika
context: Lenny asks Anton about what jobs will be more important and what skills will be less important as AI tools like Lovable become more prevalent. Anton responds that being a generalist who can do multiple things is becoming much more valuable than specialization. He emphasizes that when building product teams now, he would focus intensely on hiring people with diverse skill sets rather than narrow specialists.
vocabulary_highlights: as many skill sets as possible
text_ko: 이것저것 조금씩 해보는 거예요. 제너럴리스트(generalist)가 예전보다 훨씬 더 중요해진 것 같아요. 지금 프로덕트 팀(product team)을 꾸린다면, 뽑는 사람 한 명 한 명이 가능한 한 많은 스킬셋(skill sets)을 갖추도록 정말 집착할 거예요.
text_zh: 什么都会一点儿。现在当个多面手，我觉得比以前重要多了。如果我现在要组建一个产品团队，我会特别在意每个招进来的人都尽可能掌握更多技能。
text_es: Hacer de todo un poco. Ser generalista, creo que es mucho más importante ahora que antes. Si estoy armando un equipo de producto hoy en día, me obsesionaría con conseguir la mayor cantidad de habilidades posibles en cada persona que contrate.

text: Explaining exactly what you expect and what you're not getting is even more important with AI than with the humans. So I'm going into hooking up more of the actual functionality, but first I'll actually show you something.
speaker: Anton Osika
context: During a live demo where Anton is showing how to build an Airbnb clone with Lovable, Lenny comments on how being a good product manager with clear communication skills is important when working with AI tools. Anton responds that being precise about expectations and clearly explaining what's working versus what's not working is actually more critical when working with AI than with human engineers.
text_ko: 사람보다 인공지능(AI)에게는 기대하는 바와 받지 못하고 있는 부분을 정확히 설명하는 게 훨씬 더 중요해요. 그래서 실제 기능들을 더 연동하려고 하는데, 먼저 뭔가 하나 보여드릴게요.
text_zh: 跟AI说清楚你想要什么、现在缺什么，这比跟人沟通还要重要。所以接下来我要连接更多实际功能，不过先给你们演示点东西看看。
text_es: Explicar exactamente qué esperas y qué no estás obteniendo es aún más importante con la IA que con las personas. Así que me voy a meter de lleno en conectar más de la funcionalidad real, pero primero te voy a enseñar algo.

text: These tools as we see here, they're already very good, it looks really good as well, but mainly I would say they're getting better very, very fast. And I'd say one of the bigger bottlenecks is now they're not integrated into the current way that you have your existing products and so on. But since they're getting better so fast, I think the best thing for people who are interested in this or interested in just being a part of the future economies, get your hands very dirty with these tools because being in the top 10% in using them is going to absolutely set you apart in the coming months and years.
speaker: Anton Osika
context: After completing a demo where he built an Airbnb clone in minutes, Lenny marvels at what AI tools can now accomplish. Anton acknowledges that while these tools are already impressive, they're improving at an extremely rapid pace. He identifies integration with existing products as a current limitation, but strongly advises people to start using these tools extensively now, arguing that expertise with AI tools will be a major competitive advantage in the near future.
text_ko: 여기 보시다시피 이 도구들은 이미 꽤 좋고 시각적으로도 훌륭해요. 무엇보다도 지금 아주, 정말 빠르게 좋아지고 있어요. 다만 지금 큰 병목 중 하나는 이 도구들이 기존 제품이나 현재의 운영 방식에 잘 통합(integrated)되어 있지 않다는 점이에요. 그런데 개선 속도가 워낙 빠르니, 이 분야에 관심이 있거나 앞으로의 경제(future economies)에 참여하고 싶은 분들은 직접 깊이 다뤄보는 게 가장 좋아요. 이 도구들을 잘 다루는 상위 10%(top 10%)에 들면 앞으로 몇 달, 몇 년 사이에 확실히 차별화될 거예요.
text_zh: 你看这些工具，现在已经很厉害了，效果也确实不错，但我觉得最主要的是它们进步得特别特别快。现在比较大的一个瓶颈就是，它们还没有很好地融入到你现有的产品体系里面。但是因为它们发展得这么快，我觉得对于那些对这个领域感兴趣的人，或者想要跟上未来经济趋势的人来说，最好的办法就是赶紧上手去用这些工具，因为如果你能做到使用水平排在前10%，那在接下来的几个月甚至几年里，你绝对会脱颖而出。
text_es: Estas herramientas, como vemos aquí, ya están muy buenas, se ven realmente bien, pero yo diría que lo más importante es que están mejorando súper rápido. Y creo que uno de los cuellos de botella más grandes es que todavía no están integradas con la forma actual en que tienes tus productos existentes y todo eso. Pero como están mejorando tan rápido, creo que lo mejor para la gente que esté interesada en esto o que quiera ser parte de las economías del futuro, es meterse de lleno con estas herramientas, porque estar en el top 10% usándolas te va a posicionar completamente diferente en los próximos meses y años.

text: It takes a lot to master using tools like Lovable and being very curious and patient and we have something called chat mode where you can just ask to understand like, 'How does this work? I'm not getting what I want here, am I missing something? What should I do?' Is the best way to be productive is also one of the best ways to just learn about how software engineering works, which is you don't have to write the code anymore, but it is useful to understand how software engin- or how building products works. So I think that's the patience and curiosity is super useful.
speaker: Anton Osika
context: Lenny asks Anton for the single most important tip he would give someone using Lovable for the first time. Anton emphasizes that mastering AI tools requires significant effort, curiosity, and patience. He recommends using Lovable's chat mode to ask questions when things aren't working as expected, explaining that this approach not only improves productivity but also helps users learn fundamental software engineering concepts without needing to write code themselves.
text_ko: Lovable 같은 도구(Lovable)를 잘 다루려면 정말 많은 연습과 호기심, 인내가 필요해요. 그리고 '챗 모드(chat mode)'라는 기능이 있어서 "이게 어떻게 작동하죠? 원하는 게 안 나오는데 제가 뭘 놓치고 있나요? 어떻게 해야 하나요?"처럼 그냥 물어보면서 이해할 수 있어요. 생산적으로 일하는 가장 좋은 방법이자 소프트웨어 엔지니어링(software engineering)이 어떻게 돌아가는지 배우는 좋은 방법 중 하나는 더 이상 직접 코드를 써야 하는 건 아니지만, 그래도 소프트웨어 엔지니어링이나 제품 개발(product development)이 어떻게 이루어지는지 이해하는 게 유용하다는 점이에요. 그래서 인내심과 호기심이 정말 큰 도움이 된다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 要掌握Lovable这样的工具确实需要下不少功夫，得特别有好奇心和耐心。我们有个聊天模式(chat mode)，你可以直接问比如"这个怎么用啊？我怎么搞不出想要的效果，是不是漏了什么？我该怎么办？"这样既能提高效率，也是了解软件工程原理的最好方法之一。虽然现在不用自己写代码了，但懂得软件工程或者说产品开发的原理还是很有用的。所以我觉得保持耐心和好奇心真的很重要。
text_es: Para dominar herramientas como Lovable se necesita mucha curiosidad y paciencia, y tenemos algo que se llama modo chat (chat mode) donde simplemente puedes preguntar para entender, tipo: "¿Cómo funciona esto? No estoy consiguiendo lo que quiero, ¿se me está escapando algo? ¿Qué debería hacer?" Es la mejor manera de ser productivo y también una de las mejores formas de aprender cómo funciona la ingeniería de software, o sea, ya no tienes que escribir el código, pero sí es útil entender cómo funciona la ingeniería de software o cómo se construyen productos. Entonces creo que esa paciencia y curiosidad es súper valiosa.

text: I think raw cognitive capability is the strongest, the strongest correlate of being at Lovable. But there is this startup mindset that I think is also very strong. Being much more interested in moving very fast and iterating fast, then having a lot of structure, a lot of process and thinking about the business as a whole. More than thinking about my specific profession, my specific craft that I'm seeing myself wanting to dig into on me.
speaker: Anton Osika
context: Lenny asks Anton what attributes are common among the people he's hired for his rapidly growing startup. Anton identifies raw cognitive ability as the strongest predictor of success at Lovable, but also emphasizes the importance of having a startup mindset. He describes this as preferring rapid iteration over heavy structure and processes, and thinking holistically about the business rather than focusing narrowly on one's specific professional role or craft.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 순수한 인지 능력(raw cognitive capability)이 러버블 단계(Lovable)에 있는 것과 가장 강한 상관관계가 있는 것 같아요. 하지만 스타트업 마인드셋(startup mindset)도 아주 강하다고 봐요. 많은 구조나 프로세스를 갖추는 것보다는 훨씬 더 빠르게 움직이고 빠르게 반복(iterate fast)하는 것에 더 관심이 있어요. 제 구체적인 직업이나 특정 기술을 더 깊이 파고들고 싶어 하는 것보다는요.
text_zh: 我觉得纯粹的认知能力是在Lovable最重要的素质。但还有一种创业心态(startup mindset)也特别关键。就是更愿意快速行动、快速迭代(iterating)，而不是搞一大堆架构啊、流程啊什么的，要从整个业务的角度去思考问题。不能只盯着自己那一亩三分地，只想着怎么在自己的专业领域里钻研。
text_es: Creo que la capacidad cognitiva pura es lo más importante, la correlación más fuerte para estar en Lovable. Pero también está esta mentalidad de startup que considero súper importante. Estar mucho más interesado en moverse muy rápido e iterar rápido, que en tener un montón de estructura, un montón de procesos y pensar en el negocio como un todo. Más que pensar en mi profesión específica, en mi área específica en la que me veo queriendo profundizar.
